channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: US Blocks Russia’s Access to Dollars for Bond Payments
item.description: The U.S. Treasury tightened its restrictions on Russian financial transactions on Monday, when more than half a billion dollars in bond payments were due.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Treasury Department said its move would create additional problems for Russia’s financial system.

item.title: Up-Close Ukraine Atrocity Photographs Touch a Global Nerve
item.description: The apparent execution of Ukrainian civilians by retreating Russian forces, their bodies strewn in streets and yards, has focused attention on what constitutes crimes in war.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tatyana Petrovna, 72, in the garden of a Bucha home where the bodies of three civilians lay on Monday.

item.title: In the rubble of a town near Kyiv, many are missing and feared dead.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Photographs by Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gaping hole in a large apartment building of Borodyanka, Ukraine, laid bare its destruction after weeks of bombardment and fighting. Below, residents crowded a pick-up truck distributing aid after their town was recaptured by Ukrainian forces.

item.title: After Russian advances, U.S., Britain and Australia expand partnership to develop hypersonic missiles.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: An Australian Collins class submarine, front, and a British nuclear-powered attack sub in Perth last year.

item.title: Some Ukrainian Refugees Are Returning Home, Despite the Risks
item.description: A growing number of families, convinced the war could last for years, have decided that facing danger at home is better than life as a refugee.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Homecoming: Mariia Seniuk, left, with her two daughters, arriving from Szczecin, Poland, at the main bus terminal in Lviv, Ukraine. “Home is home,” she said.

item.title: The ‘next pivotal battle’ in Ukraine? Sloviansk, military analysts say.
item.description: A new report says Russia needs to seize the city or its campaign to capture eastern Ukraine “will likely fail.”
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Members of the Ukrainian National Guard patrolling a square in Sloviansk in early February.

item.title: Hackers’ Fake Claims of Ukrainian Surrender Aren’t Fooling Anyone. So What’s Their Goal?
item.description: Experts say the hackers’ intentions might not be to actually trick anyone, but to erode confidence in Ukrainian media outlets and institutions.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in Irpin last week. Since Russia’s invasion began, hackers have repeatedly broken into the social media accounts and broadcasting systems of trusted information sources in Ukraine.

item.title: Russians’ Flight Suits Weren’t a Political Statement, NASA Astronaut Says
item.description: The Russians were “kind of blindsided,” that people thought they were making a political statement, Mark Vande Hei said. But the suits matched the colors of the university they all attended.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: Three Russian astronauts wore flight suits that included the colors of the Ukrainian flag when they arrived at the International Space Station in March.

item.title: Oklahoma Lawmakers Approve Near-Total Ban on Abortion
item.description: The measure is part of a wave of stringent abortion restrictions enacted by legislators in Republican-led states.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Sarah Phipps/The Oklahoman, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Supporters of abortion rights rallied in front of the State Capitol in Oklahoma City on Tuesday.

item.title: The US Economy Is Booming. Why Are Economists Worrying About a Recession?
item.description: There is little sign that a recession is imminent. But sky-high demand and supply shortages are testing the economy’s limits.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: The rapid rebound in consumer spending has overwhelmed supply chains, driving up prices.

item.title: Ukraine War Reverberates in Europe’s Factories and Warehouses
item.description: European companies that relied on Russian customers are suffering collateral damage from the invasion of Ukraine and Western sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Clara Vannucci for The New York Times
item.media:description: Raimondo Amaranti, left, overseeing the making of ballerina slippers intended for Russia at the Italian shoemaker Sergio Amaranti.

item.title: Truck Drivers’ On-the-Job Training Can Be Costly if They Quit
item.description: Freight haulers draw rookie drivers by promising to get them licensed. The obligation that follows, one lawyer says, amounts to indentured servitude.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Butrymowicz and Meredith Kolodner
item.media:credit: Sean Rayford for The New York Times
item.media:description: Each year, thousands of people sign up for training with some of the biggest freight haulers. Nine in 10 drivers leave their jobs within a year at large carriers.

item.title: France’s Far Right Turn
item.description: A rising nationalist faction has grown its coalition by appealing to Catholic identity and anti-immigrant sentiment — and reshaped the country’s race for president.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Zerofsky

item.title: For Macron, France’s Troubled Industries Hit Home
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron vowed an economic revival, but as he seeks re-election, a Potemkin factory in the town where he was raised shows just how hard that can be.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The site of the Whirlpool plant in Amiens, France. Mr. Macron promised to save the factory, and his government poured millions in subsidies toward its reinvention.

item.title: Jewish Man’s Death Near Paris Fuels Outrage on Election Eve
item.description: Newly surfaced video shows the man, who was hit by a tram in February, fleeing an assault. It has fueled suspicions of an antisemitic motive days before France’s presidential vote.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: The prosecutor in the case, Éric Mathais, said his office was questioning witnesses in the death of Jérémy Cohen but that it had not yet determined what had motivated the assault.

item.title: Tiger Woods Says He Intends to Play the Masters
item.description: Woods, who sustained significant leg injuries in a single-car crash in February 2021, has played several practice rounds at Augusta National this week.
item.dc:creator: Bill Pennington and Alan Blinder
item.media:description: Tiger Woods on his way to the first tee during a practice round at Augusta National Golf Club on Monday.

item.title: Reliving How Tiger Woods Won the 1997 Masters
item.description: Tiger Woods was not supposed to win the 1997 Masters, but when he did, by 12 strokes — one of 20 Masters records he set in that tournament — he remade the game and catapulted himself to stardom.
item.dc:creator: Bill Pennington

item.title: Masters Invitations Endure as a Signature Detail for the Tournament
item.description: Putting and chipping aside, a crucial step on the journey to winning a coveted green jacket is making sure to R.S.V.P.
item.dc:creator: Alan Blinder and Doug Mills

item.title: Antiques Dealer Vito Giallo, Who Worked for Andy Warhol, Unearths His Gems
item.description: Vito Giallo, 91, looks back at a life full of treasures.
item.dc:creator: Kate Dwyer

item.title: Molly Shannon, of Saturday Night Live, Has a New Memoir, “Hello Molly!”
item.description: In a new memoir, “Hello, Molly!”, Shannon — the “Saturday Night Live” alumna — recounts her comedy career and the devastating family tragedy that changed her life.
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff
item.media:credit: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Molly Shannon is known for her plucky, determined characters — a spirit that’s vivid in her new memoir.

item.title: Rags-to-Riches Stories Are Actually Kind of Disturbing
item.description: From Horatio Alger and E.L. James to T. Boone Pickens and Charles Koch, books by and about the ultrawealthy reveal some of our darkest American fantasies.
item.dc:creator: Lydia Kiesling

item.title: Ke Huy Quan: From Short Round to Romantic Lead After Four Long Decades
item.description: A child star in the 1980s, he hit a dry patch and turned to stunt work in the 2000s. Now he has returned to acting in a part that blends his action and drama chops.
item.dc:creator: Robert Ito
item.media:credit: Jennelle Fong for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I didn’t grow up wanting to be an actor,” Ke Huy Quan said. When he was older and determined to act, “there were just not a lot of offers.”

item.title: For 25 Years, My Dad Helped Build Weapons of Death
item.description: My father fled Vietnam only to spend the rest of his life in American factories helping shore up the same military that had set our family adrift.
item.dc:creator: Thuy Linh Tu
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Why Are Adults Falling for the ‘Furries’ Myth?
item.description: The culture war is also a generational war.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.media:description: High school students in Tampa, Fla., protesting the so-called Don’t Say Gay bill.

item.title: After the Pandemic, I Want My Life to Be Less Convenient
item.description: The pandemic turned many of us into hermits. It’s time to go out again.
item.dc:creator: Michal Leibowitz

item.title: Amazon Fought Workers Trying to Unionize, and It Backfired
item.description: The successful organization of a warehouse in Staten Island offers a real glimmer of hope for the American working class.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: DeSean McClinton-Holland for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Amazon Labor Union organizing committee celebrating its victory.

item.title: College Became the Default. Let’s Rethink That.
item.description: Imagine a world that gave high schoolers more options.
item.dc:creator: John McWhorter
item.category: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

item.title: Putin’s War Has Started a Global Food Crisis
item.description: These are the countries that will be most affected by rising food prices.
item.dc:creator: Sara Menker and Rajiv Shah

item.title: A Viral Case Against Crypto, Explored
item.description: The video essayist Dan Olson explains the dangers lurking in the culture and ideology that surround digital currency.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: Inside Shanghai’s Covid-19 Lockdown
item.description: What it’s like to lock down after two years free of Covid worries.
item.dc:creator: Juli Min
item.media:description: A worker walking next to barriers separating buildings from the street during Covid-19 lockdowns in Shanghai on March 30.

item.title: Can Congressional Democrats Make a Deal on Covid Spending With Mitt Romney?
item.description: It’s time to stop slathering so much attention on Joe Manchin.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Cottle
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times

item.title: The Ruble Has Bounced Back. What Does That Mean?
item.description: Russia’s financial position is stronger in the short term than many expected.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; photograph via CSA Images/Getty

item.title: Ditch the Oil, and the Petro-Dictators Too
item.description: Responses to a column by Thomas L. Friedman. Also: The true patriots; Covid choices of strangers; wildflowers.

item.title: A Small Earthquake on Staten Island
item.description: Why a pro-union vote at Amazon may be a big deal.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: DeSean McClinton-Holland for The New York Times
item.media:description: Union supporters marched outside the Amazon warehouse on Staten Island two weeks ago.

item.title: California’s Drought Is Worse Than We Thought
item.description: Our tools for managing water in the West are growing more inaccurate.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Schwartz

item.title: Americans on Medicaid Could Soon Lose Health Insurance
item.description: Millions of Americans may lose their Medicaid coverage.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Rosenthal
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

item.title: The Kids Are Right About Email, Too
item.description: It is now just a way to be at the beck and call of anyone, and any robot, with an internet connection.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl
item.media:credit: Carla Ciuffo for The New York Times

item.title: Gardening Advice, Homelessness Solutions and Questions About Charter Schools
item.description: Readers weigh in.
item.dc:creator: Jay Caspian Kang

item.title: How Can the World Respond to Russian Atrocities? Weapons and Sanctions
item.description: How can the world respond to Russian atrocities?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destruction in Bucha, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: How the War in Ukraine is Creating a Global Food Crisis
item.description: Russia’s invasion has severely disrupted how the world feeds itself.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Rob Szypko, Rachel Quester, Michael Johnson, Liz O. Baylen, Chelsea Daniel, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.media:description: A crop field in Ukraine. Since the invasion last month, wheat prices have increased by 21 percent, barley by 33 percent and some fertilizers by 40 percent.

item.title: Life in an E.R. During Covid
item.description: Thomas Fisher talks about “The Emergency,” and Maud Newton discusses “Ancestor Trouble.”
item.category: The Emergency: A Year of Healing and Heartbreak in a Chicago ER (Book)
Ancestor Trouble: A Reckoning and a Reconciliation (Book)
item.media:description: Thomas Fisher, the author of “The Emergency: A Year of Healing and Heartbreak in a Chicago ER.”

item.title: Nutrition Tips for Runners: Your Questions, Answered
item.description: What’s the real benefit in refueling soon after a run? Can eating mid-run help speed recovery? Your nutrition questions, answered.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg
item.media:credit: Joshua Bright for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bananas may be the breakfast of choice for many runners. But there are plenty of other options, too.

item.title: Ivanka Trump Testifies to House Panel Investigating Jan. 6 Attack
item.description: The former president’s daughter and adviser was in the West Wing with him as a pro-Trump mob stormed the Capitol. She is said to have tried to persuade him to call off the rioters.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The schedule for Ivanka Trump’s testimony comes days after her husband, Jared Kushner, sat for an interview with the panel.

item.title: Louis C.K.’s Grammy Victory Leads to Backlash
item.description: Some comedians are questioning how the Recording Academy saw fit to bestow an award to someone who had admitted to sexual misconduct.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik
item.media:description: Louis C.K. in 2016.

item.title: Elon Musk Joins Twitter Board
item.description: After becoming Twitter’s largest shareholder, Elon Musk, Tesla’s chief executive, is joining the social media company’s board of directors.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Miguel Roberts/The Brownsville Herald, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Elon Musk is joining Twitter’s board after buying a big stake in the company.

item.title: Severe Weather in the South: What to Know About the Forecast
item.description: A tornado touched down in South Carolina on Tuesday afternoon as nearly five million people across a large swath of the Southeast remained under an enhanced risk of severe weather.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Elias Valverde Ii/The Dallas Morning News, via Associated Press

item.title: Fred Upton, House Republican Who Voted to Impeach Trump, Will Retire
item.description: Mr. Upton is the fourth House Republican who supported impeaching former President Donald Trump to decline to run for re-election.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:description: Representative Fred Upton was facing a difficult primary campaign against Representative Bill Huizenga, who has been endorsed by former President Donald J. Trump.

item.title: E.P.A. to Propose Restrictions on Asbestos
item.description: The agency aims to ban the manufacturing and import of a type of asbestos that is used in brake pads, gaskets and other automotive products and is linked to cancer.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Workers removed asbestos-laden debris exposed by the Tubbs Fire in Santa Rosa, Calif., in 2017.

item.title: Stolen Darwin Notebooks, Missing for Decades, Are Returned
item.description: The two notebooks were anonymously returned to the Cambridge University Library 22 years after they went missing. A note addressed to the librarian read: “Happy Easter.”
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: One of the returned notebooks included Charles Darwin’s famous “tree of life” drawing, which maps out how related species could diverge from a common ancestor.

item.title: Ann Sarnoff, Warner Bros. Chief, Is Set to Leave
item.description: Ms. Sarnoff became the first woman to hold the job in 2019, but Discovery’s C.E.O. is expected to take over at least some of her role himself.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes

item.title: More Evidence Bolsters Durham’s Case Against Democratic-Linked Lawyer
item.description: Separately, defense lawyers asked a judge to block the Trump-era special counsel from making the Steele dossier a focus of next month’s trial.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: MLB Approves PitchCom to Limit Sign Stealing
item.description: PitchCom devices will let catchers communicate secretly with pitchers and up to three fielders during games.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.media:description: Major League Baseball has attempted to address sign stealing by allowing teams to use PitchCom, a communications device that lets catchers communicate with pitchers during the game.

item.title: Anti-Abortion Activists Claim They Had 115 Fetuses From Clinic
item.description: A medical waste disposal company denied their account. Most of the fetuses were buried in secret, the activists said, but they kept five that were later seized by the police in Washington, D.C.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: The anti-abortion activist Lauren Handy spoke at a news conference on Tuesday about the five fetuses that the police in Washington, D.C., seized from her home last week.

item.title: How to Prepare for BA.2, the Omicron Subvariant
item.description: Taking these seven steps now can lower your risk and minimize the disruption to your family’s life.
item.dc:creator: Tara Parker-Pope and Knvul Sheikh

item.title: Covid Vaccines for Kids Are Dividing Divorced Parents
item.description: For some parents who share custody, the Covid vaccine has created a minefield of issues that initial divorce decrees could not have anticipated.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin

item.title: What to Do When There Is a Tornado Warning
item.description: A tornado warning demands instant action. Here’s what to do if one comes your way, and how you can prepare in advance.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Joseph Rushmore for The New York Times
item.media:description: Locust Grove, Okla., in 2019. Severe storms in the area brought about several tornado warnings.

item.title: How Men’s Bodies Change When They Become Fathers
item.description: Hint: They don’t just get “dad bods.”
item.dc:creator: Anna Machin

item.title: What’s the Best Advice You’ve Received About Motherhood?
item.description: Your response may be used in an upcoming story.
item.dc:creator: Melonyce McAfee
item.media:credit: Zerb Mellish for The New York Times

item.title: Review: ‘The Trayvon Generation,’ by Elizabeth Alexander
item.description: “The Trayvon Generation” traces the influences of racism and violence on American culture today.
item.dc:creator: Mitchell S. Jackson
item.media:credit: Dawoud Bey. Courtesy: Sean Kelly, New York.
item.media:description: “I call the young people who grew up in the past 25 years the Trayvon Generation,” Elizabeth Alexander writes — including the women in Dawoud Bey’s “Martina and Rhonda, Chicago, Ill.,” 1993.

item.title: Restaurant Review: Mena in TriBeCa
item.description: The former chef of Chumley’s wasn’t put on this earth to cook bar food, as she proves with her striking new place in TriBeCa.
item.dc:creator: Pete Wells
item.media:credit: Rachel Vanni for The New York Times

item.title: Louis Head Inspired New Rule for Optioning Players to Minors
item.description: Head was optioned to the minors 12 times by Tampa Bay in 2021, setting a record and inspiring a new rule. Now in Miami, he just might stick around.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Kepner

item.title: Love and Scandal, Buried for Years at an Elite Boarding School
item.description: In Jonathan Galassi’s “School Days,” a sexual harassment investigation uncovers long-buried memories of desire and abuse.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Lybarger
item.media:description: Jonathan Galassi’s novel “School Days” explores desire and abuse at an elite boarding school.

item.title: An E-Commerce Site for Ukrainian Fashion
item.description: Angel for Fashion hopes to bring Ukrainian designs to customers all over the world — except Russia.
item.dc:creator: Shane O’Neill
